summary: This is an FBI FD-759 form authorizing consensual electronic monitoring in the investigation of Alfredo Rodriguez for obstruction of justice. The document details a scheme where Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein to attorney Bradley J. Edwards for $50,000. Edwards, who is representing four female plaintiffs, agreed to cooperate with the FBI by making a monitored call to Rodriguez.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Subject of Investigation / Former Epstein Employee
persons.context: Former employee of Jeffrey Epstein who is attempting to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein to attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000, leading to an obstruction of justice investigation.

persons.name: Bradley J. Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing four female plaintiffs in a civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein. He was contacted by Alfredo Rodriguez and is cooperating with the FBI by consenting to monitor calls with Rodriguez as part of the investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of a civil lawsuit brought by four female individuals represented by Bradley J. Edwards. His former employee, Alfredo Rodriguez, possesses documents related to this case.

persons.name: Gavin Gumbinner
persons.context: Listed as the author of the FBI FD-759 electronic monitoring authorization form.

connections.description: Rodriguez was an employee for Epstein, as stated in the investigation synopsis.
Edwards, an attorney suing Epstein, was contacted by Rodriguez who attempted to sell him case-related documents. Edwards is now cooperating with the FBI to investigate Rodriguez's actions.
Edwards is the attorney representing four female individuals who are suing Jeffrey Epstein in a civil case.

events.title: Rodriguez Contacts Edwards About Documents
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez contacted attorney Bradley J. Edwards and offered to sell him documents pertinent to the civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI Authorizes Consensual Monitoring
events.description: The FBI authorized the use of electronic monitoring equipment for a consensual call between Bradley J. Edwards and Alfredo Rodriguez, facilitated by an Undercover Employee (UCE), to complete the document transaction.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell documents related to a civil lawsuit against Epstein to attorney Bradley J. Edwards for $50,000.
Bradley J. Edwards, who represents four female plaintiffs suing Epstein, reported the scheme to the FBI and agreed to cooperate in a consensual monitoring operation.

The FBI authorized electronic monitoring on October 28, 2009, for Edwards to call Rodriguez and introduce an Undercover Employee (UCE) to complete the transaction, investigating potential obstruction of justice.
The document reveals an active FBI investigation into obstruction of justice (violations of 18 U.S.C. 1509 & 1510) stemming from the civil litigation against Jeffrey Epstein.
The investigation synopsis confirms the existence of a civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein involving four female individuals represented by Bradley J. Edwards.
